title: Arriving in Lund
text: There are many ways through which you can reach the conference in Lund.

title: Arriving in Lund
text:
Airline access
The closest international airport to Lund is Copenhagen Airport (CPH), in Denmark. It‚Äôs the most accessible airport in Scandinavia and most international airlines operate into it. The airport is only a 40-minute train ride from Lund and takes you over the Oresund Bridge connecting Denmark to Sweden.

title: Arriving in Lund
text:
Train access
International train connections are available mainly to Copenhagen Central Station, from where regional trains depart for Lund, passing by the airport on the way. Lund is also a major stop on the national Swedish railway system, e.g., a four-hour ride from Stockholm.

title: Arriving in Lund
text:
Public Transport
Public transport in Sweden in general, and in the Malm√∂/Lund/Copenhagen region in particular, is modern, very accessible, and convenient. Local trains run frequently (every 5‚Äì10 min) between Lund-Malm√∂ and every 20 min between Lund and Copenhagen. The WEHC area is less than a 10-minute walk from Lund railway station. Within the town of Lund, the city buses and trams are easily accessible and offer convenient transportation with good pricing, reaching all parts of Lund.
In the town center of Lund, the most convenient way of transportation is walking or bicycling.

title: Important Notice
text:
Important Notice: Beware of Potential Spam Emails
It has come to our attention that some participants may have received an email from an address such as support@g-travelexperts.com, claiming to arrange accommodation for the World Economic History Congress 2025 in Lund this July.
We would like to inform all participants that this email is not associated with the World Economic History Congress 2025 or any of its official arrangements. This is likely a spam or phishing attempt.
To protect yourself, we strongly advise:

Do not reply to such emails.

Avoid clicking on any links or providing personal information.

Mark the email as spam and delete it immediately.

Please note that all official communication regarding the Congress, including accommodation arrangements, will come directly from our organizing team via our official email address: wehc2025@ekh.lu.se.
We encourage participants to share this information with their networks to ensure that everyone is aware of this issue.
Thank you for your cooperation and understanding,
Igor Martins, on behalf of the WEHC 2025 organizing committee

title: Call for sessions
text:
The deadline for submissions is now closed. If you want to edit your submission, please, visit this link. If you have any further questions, message the organizing committee at wehc2025@ekh.lu.se.
The 20th World Economic History Congress will convene from 28 July‚Äì1 August 2025 in Lund, Sweden. The theme for the Congress is Equality and Sustainability Challenges, which highlights some of the central issues facing humanity today and also connects to a broad and diverse range of historical problems. To address both the challenges and to find insights from the historical record for that endeavour, a range of perspectives will be necessary.
The IEHA has a particularly strong desire to attract sessions related to this theme. However, submissions are welcome on the economic and social histories of all places and periods, and on the exploration of varied sources and methods, and on the theory and uses of economic history itself. We also invite members to employ and analyse diverse strategies for representing the past.
Sessions may be proposed by any member of the international economic history community, whatever their institutional affiliation or status, as well as by scholars in related disciplines. Given the diversity of our membership, we will consider any submission that advances the study, teaching and public presentation of economic history. We welcome panel proposals that highlight scholarship emerging from economic history, business history, financial history, demographic history, environmental history, global and world history, social history, urban and agrarian history, gender studies, material culture, methodological approaches to historical research, history of economics and economic thought, science and technology studies, and other related fields.
The programme of the Lund Congress will be organised on the same principles as previous Congresses. The 5-day Congress will have approximately 180 sessions, with each day divided into time blocks of 90 minutes each (two before lunch and two after lunch). As in the past, it will be possible to combine two sessions into larger coherent units.
The session proposals should contain:

Name, title, affiliation, and contact information of the session organiser
Possible co-organisers (optional)
Title of the session
Description of the session‚Äôs aim, contribution, and relevance (max 5,000 characters with blanks)
Researchers invited to participate in the session, or those already confirmed, and their affiliations

title: Call for dissertations
text:
The World Economic History Congress will dedicate three sessions on Monday 28 July 2025 for the PhD dissertation competition. The sessions and prizes are divided according to the dissertations‚Äô main time focus ‚Äì before the 19th century, the long 19th century, or the 20th and 21st centuries. A review group will beforehand read the thesis and listen to the participants‚Äô presentations. The Prize winners will be announced at the Congress festivities Wednesday evening 30 July.
Eligible to participate are PhD graduates who successfully defended their thesis between 1 September 2021 and 31 December 2024. The subject of the thesis must be Economic history, but can, of course, have been defended in neighboring disciplines, for example, Economics or History.
Apply by emailing wehc2025@ekh.lu.se. Enter ‚ÄúDissertation session‚Äù in the subject box. The mail must state your name, affiliation, the title of the thesis, the time focus of your dissertation according to the division above, where and when the thesis was defended, and an electronic link to the full-text thesis.
Send your application no later than 10 January 2025.

title: Just a kind reminder‚Ä¶
text:
Dear colleagues,
I hope this message finds you well. As part of the organizing committee for the World Economic History Congress 2025, I would like to remind you of a few important steps to ensure the smooth organization of the sessions.
A preliminary schedule is now available on the conference website, and we kindly ask you to review it. For the time being, only the names of the organizers and participants are available. Please confirm the names of all participants in the session you are organizing, and ensure that their presentation or paper titles, as well as their affiliations, are added to the session information. Editing the session details can be done directly through the submission portal. We encourage you to do this as soon as possible, but not later than March 15th. Timely updates not only assist us in allocating rooms appropriately but also enable us to publish the final schedule earlier, which will help participants plan their travel arrangements more effectively.
Additionally, we would like to remind you that February 15th at 23:59 (CET) is the deadline for early bird registration. If you or your participants wish to take advantage of this option, please ensure that registration is completed before this date. If you cannot pay by card or need your employer/funder to pay on your behalf, we can issue invoices. If this is the case, please, message the organizing committee directly so we can assist you.
If you have any additional questions or need further assistance, please feel free to contact us at wehc2025@ekh.lu.se. We look forward to welcoming you to Lund in 2025!

On behalf of the WEHC 2025 Organizing Committee Igor Martins Senior Lecturer Department of Economic History, Lund University

text:

Lund Cathedral
A Romanesque cathedral built in the early 1100s, Lund Cathedral is one of Scandinavia‚Äôs oldest and most significant religious buildings. The crypt, with its carved stone pillars, and the medieval astronomical clock are highlights of any visit.


Botanical Gardens
Located near the conference venues, Lund‚Äôs Botanical Gardens are open daily and free to enter. With more than 7,000 species and beautifully arranged walking paths, it‚Äôs an ideal place to relax or take a mindful stroll between sessions.


Streets of Lund
Lund‚Äôs historic city centre is best explored on foot. Wander cobbled alleys, pass by centuries-old houses, and enjoy the atmosphere around university squares and quiet courtyards. Caf√©s and bookstores line the walkways, offering plenty of opportunities to pause.

title: Call for book sessions
text:
The 20th World Economic History Congress invites you, who recently published a scholarly book with economic historical content, to present it at special sessions during the WEHC from 28 July ‚Äì 1 August 2025.

Apply by emailing wehc2025@ekh.lu.se. Enter ‚ÄúBook session‚Äù in the subject box. The mail must state your name, affiliation, the title of the book, the publisher, and when it was or is to be published.

title: Keynote speakers
text:
Elise van Nederveen Meerkerk


Work, Gender, Race and Class: Towards Intersectional Political Economics?


Elise van Nederveen Meerkerk is a professor of economic and social history and chair of the Economic and Social History group at Utrecht University, The Netherlands. She specializes in Global Labour History, with a focus on gendered and colonial labour relations. Apart from journal articles in Feminist Economics, Economic History Review, and the European Review of Economic History, Elise published a monograph entitled Women, Work and Colonialism in the Netherlands and Java. She was PI of the EU-funded ERC Consolidator research project ‚ÄúRace to the Bottom? Family Labour, Household Livelihood and Consumption in the Relocation of Global Cotton Manufacturing, ca. 1750-1990‚Äù. Currently, Elise is developing a new research project on coerced labour in the Dutch Empire.




Mar Rubio-Varas


Greening the Past, Informing the Future: Economic History‚Äôs Dual Role in Sustainability Challenges


Mar Rubio-Varas is a Professor of History and Economic Institutions at Universidad Publica de Navarra (UPNA, Spain). She specializes in the long-term relationships between energy consumption and the economy, focusing on energy dependency and transitions to low-carbon economies. She holds a PhD and Master‚Äôs from the London School of Economics and a degree in Economics from Carlos III University. Rubio-Varas leads a team researching the take-off of renewable industry in Navarra and other European regions and her research includes directing multiple EU-funded projects. Among her publications is a book on the Spanish nuclear sector (Palgrave MacMillan, 2017).




C√©sar A. Hidalgo


Big Data and Machine Learning Explorations of Economic History and Collective Memory


C√©sar A. Hidalgo is known for his contributions to economic complexity and for his applied work on data visualization and artificial intelligence. Hidalgo is a tenured professor at the Toulouse School of Economics‚Äô Department of Social and Behavioral Sciences and the head of the Center for Collective Learning. Hidalgo‚Äôs contributions have been recognized with numerous awards, including the 2018 Lagrange Prize and three Webby Awards. He has authored dozens of peer-reviewed papers and three books: Why Information Grows, The Atlas of Economic Complexity, and How Humans Judge Machines.

title: Call for sessions: member associations
text:
The deadline for submissions is now closed. If you want to edit your submission, please, visit this link. If you have any further questions, message the organizing committee at wehc2025@ekh.lu.se.
The 20th World Economic History Congress will convene from 28 July‚Äì August 2025 in Lund, Sweden. As a new initiative, the IEHA invites session proposals from member associations. Sessions can be on any area of economic and social history, but should aim to highlight work by scholars affiliated to member associations ‚Äì whether those are defined thematically or geographically.
Association sessions allow our member organizations to showcase the work of their scholars in front of a global audience, engaging with new potential members. It also enables member organizations to host meetings without incurring the overhead costs of renting space or basis.
Other opportunities for member associations to publicise their activities at the meeting will include a dedicated table in the publishers‚Äô area where associations can display literature or copies of their journals. There will also be meeting space available during the breaks for member associations to hold their own organizational meetings.
The member society session proposals should contain:

Name of the member society proposing the session
Contact information
Title of the session
Description of the session‚Äôs aim, contribution, and relevance (max 5,000 characters with blanks)
Researchers invited to participate in the session, or those already confirmed, and their affiliations

title: Public Lectures
text:
Public Lectures during WEHC 2025
In collaboration with the City of Lund, we are organising three public lectures in Swedish (the first possibly in Danish/Swedish). All speakers are participants in the congress, and the events are aimed at the general public. No prior registration is required, but please arrive early in case the venue becomes full.

Tuesday 29 July 18:00, Stadshallen, Botulfsh√∂rnan
Det danska imperiets uppg√•ng och fall ‚Äì med en blick p√• Sk√•nes betydelse
Michael Bregnsbo and Kurt Villads Jensen
On the historical development of Denmark and Scania from the Middle Ages onward. The speakers published a widely noted book a few years ago, offering a reinterpretation of the Danish Empire‚Äôs significance in a European context, highlighting Scania‚Äôs role as a central part of the former Danish realm.
Thursday 31 July 18:00, Stadshallen, Botulfsh√∂rnan
V√§rldens j√§mlikaste land?
Erik Bengtsson
On equality and inequality in Sweden from a historical perspective. The speaker has published books and op-eds presenting new perspectives on the drivers of changing inequality and has shown that at the start of the twentieth century, Sweden was one of Europe‚Äôs most unequal countries.
Friday 1 August 13:00, Stadshallen, Botulfsh√∂rnan
Fakta och fiktion om kvinnors arbete i historien
Malin Nilsson
On women‚Äôs work and livelihoods throughout history. The speaker, who leads a major research project on spinning in the eighteenth century, challenges the myth of the ‚Äútradwife‚Äù ‚Äì historically, women have always worked. The topic is especially timely following the 2023 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences awarded to economic historian Claudia Goldin, whose research focuses precisely on this.
